conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point.
The graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time. The particle starts from rest, so the initial velocity is 0.
The particle accelerates from 0 to \( t_0 \). Between \( t_0 \) and \( 2t_0 \), the velocity decreases back to 0. The particle continues to decelerate to a negative velocity by \( 3t_0/2 \).

From 0 to \( t_0 \), the velocity increases linearly. From \( t_0 \) to \( 2t_0 \), the velocity decreases linearly back to 0. From \( 2t_0 \) to \( 3t_0/2 \), the velocity continues to decrease into negative values.

The area under the velocity-time graph represents the displacement of the particle. From 0 to \( t_0 \), the particle moves in the positive direction. From \( t_0 \) to \( 2t_0 \), the particle slows down and eventually stops. From \( 2t_0 \) to \( 3t_0/2 \), the particle starts moving in the negative direction.
The particle reaches its maximum positive displacement before it starts moving in the negative direction. This maximum positive displacement occurs at \( t = t_0 \).
The particle is farthest from the starting point at \( t = t_0 \).
